title: Obama Calls Romney Out On Navy, Bayonets

comments.text:
What a joke. Romney owns Obama in every conceivable way - intellect, 
character, ability, honesty, experience - you name it.  Romney turned out 
to be right about everything he threw at Obama, from Russia to Iran to 
Syria to Iraq to the economy to military strength.  Every expert out there 
(including recent Secretaries of Defense) has been sounding the alarm about 
Obama's destruction of our military, and these smug 'Young Turks' now look 
like fools.  We had a chance to get Obama and his pack of idiots the HELL 
OUT, and we will pay for not doing so.﻿

comments.author: Steven Waccybaccy

comments.text:
TYT, see, YOU have no idea how our military works. If you knew anything 
about our Navy, you'd know that we have plenty of ships close to retirement 
age. The Los Angeles Class attack submarines are being retired (the largest 
submarine class in the US Navy, and the world if I'm not mistaken,) the 
Navy's looking for replacements for the Ohio class missile subs, and don't 
even get me started on the surface ships. The Navy's scrambling. Littoral 
combat ships, Zumwalt class DDG, Gerald R. Ford CVN, etc. They've 
decommissioned some of the Ticonderoga class cruisers, which I believe are 
very effective! The loadout of weapons available on that ship are just 
unmatched. The next best ship in terms of available weaponry would be the 
Burke class destroyers. DDG-51 class. We're losing plenty of ships, and in 
order to fight effectively, we need to reinforce our Navy with more 
effective ships, and we need a larger quantity. I'm not saying Obama is 
completely wrong, but neither is Romney. Obama's right in that our Navy is 
stronger than it used to be. But Romney is right in that we need more ships 
in order to be more effective.

We NEED 300 ships or more in order to operate effectively. This is the only 
thing that can stop the Chinese from effectively invading places like 
Taiwan. Because we have the best and most ships in the world. No other 
country can match our aircraft carriers. We have 10 or 11 of the best 
carriers in the world. 3 CVNs are not good enough. If we wanted, we could 
have more planes deploying from these carriers than some nations' entire 
air forces! Our new Seawolf and Virginia class attack subs are among the 
best of the best. Russia's struggling to keep up with that with their new 
submarines. If we completely followed your idea, they'd surpass us pretty 
quickly.

What we need is 300-350 ships. Not 1,000. Not 100. We need enough to be 
effective, but not so much that we deplete our resources over it. Please 
don't blindly follow politicians just to get publicity. At least do some 
research or pick topics which you have knowledge of. You demonstrated no 
knowledge of the US Navy.﻿

comments.author: Ralph Bernhard

comments.text:
+David Vilt 
Three things are clear from delving into the charts and numbers in the new 
defense budget that President Obama proposed Monday: The defense budget is 
larger, and growing faster than it might seem; most of the growth goes for 
big-ticket weapons systems like those from Cold War times; and the Army 
gets such a small share of the budget, compared with the Navy and Air 
Force, that inter-service warfare within the Pentagon is all but inevitable.
According to the Pentagon's press release the proposed budget for fiscal 
2016 amounts to $585.3 billion. However, that’s merely the sum requested 
for the Defense Department. As defined by the Office of Management and 
Budget appropriations for “national defense” also include the Energy 
Department’s nuclear weapons programs and assorted items in various other 
agencies, which together add up to $35.6 billion—putting the total request 
at $620.9 billion.
Either way, the FY16 budget request is 4 percent above the actual budget 
for FY15 (which amounted to $560.4 billion for the Defense Department, 
$596.8 billion for what the OMB called “national defense”).
However, looked at another way, Obama is asking for a much larger increase. 
The Pentagon’s documents divide the request in two parts: "the base budget" 
and the "O.C.O." standing for Overseas Contingency Operations. OCO refers 
to wars that U.S. forces are fighting in Afghanistan, Iraq, Sudan, and so 
forth. The “base” refers to everything else—money for personnel, weapons 
procurement, research and development, operations and maintenance, and so 
forth, even if there are no wars going on at the moment.
The budget for OCO is expected to go down in FY16, in keeping with the 
troop withdrawals from Afghanistan, from $64.2 billion to $50.9 
billion—about a 21 percent reduction.
The request for the base budget, on the other hand, rises very steeply, 
much more so than the figures for the overall defense budget might appear. 
To be precise, if Obama gets what he requests, the base budget will rise 
from $496.1 billion in FY15 to $534.3 billion in FY16.



Intriguingly, while the Pentagon’s “overview” briefing notes that it’s 
requesting a 4 percent increase in the total defense budget and a 21 
percent reduction in the OCO accounts, it doesn’t express the base-budget 
increase in percentage terms, so let me do the math for you: It translates 
to an increase of 7.7 percent. This is enormous.
In other words, President Obama may be getting out of President Bush’s 
wars, but he’s investing a lot more money in the Pentagon.

What’s driving this increase in spending? It’s not pay hikes (just 1.3 
percent) or military personnel (rising only from $140 billion to $140.3 
billion). No, it’s mainly weapons systems—and, in that category, mainly the 
sorts of weapons systems needed for a big war against a major power: 
aircraft carriers, stealth fighter jets, and submarines

You mean obama? What he was saying is that the nature of the military has 
changed. That pointing to number of ships is a outdated way of looking at 
it, and they are  now looking at the capabilities. And I think no one will 
deny that the navy is stronger now than it was is 1917. He used horses and 
bayonets as an example since we also have fewer of those now than we did in 
1917, and no one will deny that the military now is stronger than in 1917. 
I don't want to be captain obvious here but I don't know if you disagree 
with what Obama said or simply pointing out that some machine guns still 
have bayonet slots?
